subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: This really cool, Paul.  You definitely get geek points, and it will be very helpful for reading practice. I also missed the namer dots, can those in some
messageBody:
This really cool, Paul.  You definitely get geek points, and it will be very helpful for reading practice.

I also missed the namer dots, can those in some cases be added to the dictionary?  Certainly Pakistan is only ever a name (though I guess pakistani would not be).  That word totally threw me, by the way, since I pronounce it as "pea ah key eat see tea ah no," perhaps from watching the BBC.

I think the ideal implementation of this would be as a translating proxy server.  (I have some experience working with these).  For each web request, you fetch the page, do some complicated stuff to only select the text on the page (no HTML/script/CSS), and translate the text on the fly.  However, that is really only going to work with the Unicode font: the browser should default to it as the only available typeface with the correct characters, even though the page would be designed to use other fonts.

(And what works for HTML pages will also work for RSS.)

Of course, it is much easier to think of a solution than to implement it.  But I'd love to check out the code... just not this upcoming crazy week :)

oliver


On 10 Nov 2007, at 19:27, Paul Tremblay wrote:

Moira O'Brien wrote:
> 
> 
> I am impressed Paul. The only fault i can find with your 
> transliteration is the lack of capital letter dots in front of names, 
> but the context makes it quite clear so it does not impede reading.
> 
> I will be very interested in finding out more about how you achieve the 
> automatic conversion from TO to QS. Maybe you could find time to PM me 
> or post to the group if you think it would be of general interest.
> 

Well, here is the geek explanation. There are these thinks called rss 
feeds, which basically list all the latest news. With python, a 
programming language, you can get all of the leads with just a few lines 
of code. That is step one. Then you have to look at the link of each 
story and get the story (as opposed to just the headlines), and I do 
that with a text browser called lynx. Lynx is like any browser except it 
displays the page in plain text--a rather simple version of Firefox. 
More importantly to my purpose, it converts the news to plain text. So 
that is step two. I now have the news story in a regular text file, such 
as you would write an email in.

Then I have to get rid of all the junk on the page, since web pages are 
full of so much advertising you possibly couldn't convert them just as 
they are. I have to look for patterns. For instance, I know that the web 
pages from this site start with [3]AP, so I know I can get rid of 
everything before that. I am counting on that the same patterns will 
always be there, which they wouldn't be for other sites, or if this one 
site changed their format. In other words, I'm really hacking it here. 
Now I translate the plain text to QS which I'll explain below). Once it 
is in QS, I make a so called LaTeX file. For news, this format is 
simple. Latex will automatically generate a table of contents and it 
will use the kerning information in a font, so that the text has the 
right space between them. (I have come across some texts on line in 
which the kerning was so bad that I couldn't tell where a word ended and 
where one began, which makes reading hard.) Now I have a PDF file with 
the font embedded, so even if you didn't have the font on your system, 
you can still read the PDF with just a click. (How all PDF works.) 
Lastly, because soreforge is such a nice site and because they offer 
services for free, it allows me to automatically upload my PDF. This can 
all be done while I'm sleeping. On the other hand, there are so many 
steps that something could go wrong. I hope not, but we'll see.

The part you want to know is probably just the conversion. Writing a 
conversion program is pretty easy. You just have to break each line into 
words. Python and other such programs were built to do this. Once you 
have a list of words, you look up the match in a dictionary. That's 
where the real heart of this whole process lies--in the dictionary. I 
was lucky that there is a word data base of 100 000 words, that lists 
words with suffixes and prefixes. So a portion looks like this:

read rId
reads rIdz
reading rIdN

Or actually, that's what my word base looks like. The original consisted 
of the word in TO and the pronounciation of the word on the right, and 
it was a simple matter of changing the pronounciation to QS

You can see each line just consists of two words, one in TO, and one in 
QS as you might type on your keyboard. For each word the program finds 
in the news article, it tries to find the match in the dictionary. If it 
doesn't find one, it simply writes the original word. Otherwise, it uses 
the word it finds.

Last, the conversion part of the program can change the encoding of the 
word. It can keep the encoding in ASCII or change it to Unicode. For the 
news, I use Unicode so that the words that are not converted appear in 
TO, and those that do appear in QS.

I'm not sure how much detail you wanted. But really to sum up, to 
convert TO to QS only requires a good dictionary. The rest of the 
program could be done by anybody who trained themselves in maybe just a 
few weeks. So the quality of the translation depends on the dictionary. 
Right now I think my dictionary is adequate, but not great. What I am 
doing is creating a separate dictionary a bit at a time. I transliterate 
a Grimm's fairy tale, and unlike the news, carefully check the file. The 
program will actually list the unchecked and unfound words, so I can 
look at this list. I correct words and add them to my good dictionary.

I say this because I am hoping that others will start contributing to a 
dictionary. With a good dictionary, we could transliterate even long 
works in a short amount of time.

Mostly I prefer to do my writing and reading off of the computer. 
Unfortunately, there are not books written in QS, and I would like to 
improve my QS. So looking at the news in the morning seems a good way 
for me to do this. I can print out the PDF or versions of it and read it 
when I have a chance. I hope others can do the same. That is my 
intention, anyway.

Paul

PS Yes, name dots are sorely lacking in my transliteration. How is a 
program to know if "bush" means the shrub or the president? In the 
future I hope the program may get a bit more sophisticated to handle 
these situations. Bu some words, like Chavez, should always have a name 
dot, so that is just a matter of correcting the dictionary.
